metadata.description: Comprehensive failure modes for all 129 mental models - 5 failure modes per model

failures.name: Incentive Blindness
failures.description: Failing to identify hidden or non-obvious incentives that drive behavior
prevention_strategies: Map all stakeholders and their incentives
failures.example_scenario: Analyst concludes executives are aligned with shareholders based only on stock options, missing that vesting schedules encourage short-term manipulation

failures.name: Incentive Oversimplification
failures.description: Reducing complex multi-incentive situations to a single dominant incentive
prevention_strategies: Always identify at least 3 incentives per actor
failures.example_scenario: Assuming salespeople only respond to commission, missing that peer recognition and job security also drive behavior

failures.name: Incentive Timing Mismatch
failures.description: Ignoring the temporal dimension of incentives - when rewards/punishments are delivered matters
failures.example_scenario: Designing a bonus structure with annual payouts when quarterly behavior changes are needed

failures.name: Perverse Incentive Creation
failures.description: Proposed solutions inadvertently create incentives for undesired behavior
prevention_strategies: Apply inversion - how could this be gamed?
Review historical examples of similar incentives
failures.example_scenario: Paying bounties for dead cobras leads to cobra farming (the original Cobra Effect)

failures.name: Incentive Magnitude Miscalibration
failures.description: Incentives too weak to change behavior or so strong they cause dysfunction
failures.example_scenario: Offering a 1% bonus for safety improvements when workers can earn 20% more by cutting corners

failures.name: Affinity Bias Blindspot
failures.description: Failing to recognize when liking someone distorts objective analysis
prevention_strategies: Require independent review by someone without relationship
failures.example_scenario: Investment committee approves deal because they like the founder, ignoring red flags in financials

failures.name: Halo Effect Propagation
failures.description: Positive feelings in one domain incorrectly spread to unrelated domains
prevention_strategies: Require evidence for each positive claim
failures.example_scenario: Assuming a successful entrepreneur will also be a good board member without evidence of governance skills

failures.name: Reciprocity Contamination
failures.description: Liking someone because they did something nice, then distorting analysis to favor them
failures.example_scenario: Analyst gives favorable rating to company whose CEO invited them to exclusive event

failures.name: In-Group Favoritism
failures.description: Preferring analysis that favors people similar to oneself
failures.example_scenario: Venture capitalists consistently funding founders from their own alma mater

failures.name: Criticism Avoidance
failures.description: Softening or omitting negative findings to preserve relationships
failures.example_scenario: Auditor fails to flag issues because they want to maintain client relationship

failures.name: Negative Halo Effect
failures.description: Dislike in one area spreads to unfairly negative assessment in unrelated areas
failures.example_scenario: Dismissing a competitor's valid innovation because of personal dislike for their CEO

failures.name: Guilt by Association
failures.description: Negative judgment based on association rather than direct evidence
failures.example_scenario: Rejecting a vendor because they also serve a competitor you dislike

failures.name: Confirmation of Negative Priors
failures.description: Seeking only information that confirms pre-existing negative views
failures.example_scenario: Research report on competitor only cites negative reviews, ignoring positive customer feedback

failures.name: Proportionality Distortion
failures.description: Minor flaws magnified due to dislike, major positives minimized
failures.example_scenario: Rejecting acquisition target for minor accounting issues while ignoring strong market position

failures.name: Motivated Reasoning Against
failures.description: Constructing elaborate justifications for negative conclusions driven by emotion
failures.example_scenario: Building complex bear case for stock after losing money on previous investment in same sector

failures.name: Premature Closure
failures.description: Reaching conclusions too quickly to eliminate uncomfortable uncertainty
failures.example_scenario: CEO makes acquisition decision in one meeting to 'stop the uncertainty' without due diligence

failures.name: False Certainty
failures.description: Expressing high confidence to avoid acknowledging genuine uncertainty
failures.example_scenario: Analyst gives precise price target without acknowledging wide range of possible outcomes

failures.name: Binary Thinking
failures.description: Reducing complex situations to yes/no when reality is probabilistic
failures.example_scenario: Framing market outlook as 'bull or bear' instead of probability distribution of outcomes

failures.name: Anchoring on First Answer
failures.description: Accepting first plausible explanation to resolve doubt quickly
failures.example_scenario: Attributing sales decline to economy without considering product issues or competition

failures.name: Stress-Induced Snap Judgment
failures.description: Making quick decisions under stress to eliminate anxiety of uncertainty
failures.example_scenario: Panic selling during market crash to eliminate anxiety of watching losses

failures.name: Sunk Cost Persistence
failures.description: Continuing failed course of action to remain consistent with past decisions
prevention_strategies: Evaluate decisions fresh ignoring sunk costs
failures.example_scenario: Continuing to fund failing project because 'we've already invested so much'

failures.name: Belief Perseverance
failures.description: Maintaining beliefs despite contradictory evidence to avoid inconsistency
prevention_strategies: Require thesis revision on new data
failures.example_scenario: Maintaining bullish thesis on stock despite multiple earnings misses

failures.name: Identity-Protective Cognition
failures.description: Rejecting information that threatens self-concept or group identity
failures.example_scenario: Value investor dismissing growth investing evidence because 'that's not who we are'

failures.name: Commitment Escalation
failures.description: Increasing commitment to justify past decisions rather than cutting losses
failures.example_scenario: Doubling down on losing position to 'prove the original thesis right'

failures.name: Cognitive Dissonance Resolution via Distortion
failures.description: Distorting new information to fit existing beliefs rather than updating beliefs
failures.example_scenario: Reinterpreting missed earnings as 'actually positive because expectations were too high'

failures.name: Analysis Paralysis from Over-Curiosity
failures.description: Endless information gathering without reaching actionable conclusions
failures.example_scenario: Research team delays recommendation indefinitely because 'we need more data'

failures.name: Curiosity Misdirection
failures.description: Pursuing interesting but irrelevant tangents instead of core questions
failures.example_scenario: Deep dive into company history when the key question is about future competitive position

failures.name: Curiosity Deficit
failures.description: Insufficient curiosity leading to surface-level analysis
failures.example_scenario: Accepting management guidance without questioning underlying assumptions

failures.name: Selective Curiosity
failures.description: Being curious only about confirming information, not disconfirming
prevention_strategies: Equal research into bull and bear cases
failures.example_scenario: Deep research into growth drivers but superficial look at competitive threats

failures.name: Curiosity Without Synthesis
failures.description: Gathering information without integrating it into coherent understanding
failures.example_scenario: Report full of facts but no clear investment thesis or recommendation

failures.name: Fairness Projection
failures.description: Assuming others share your fairness standards when they don't
failures.example_scenario: Assuming competitor will maintain pricing discipline because 'it's the rational thing to do'

failures.name: Fairness-Based Overreaction
failures.description: Disproportionate response to perceived unfairness damaging own interests
failures.example_scenario: Rejecting profitable deal because terms feel 'unfair' even though they're market standard

failures.name: Fairness Definition Mismatch
failures.description: Different parties have different definitions of fair, leading to conflict
failures.example_scenario: Merger negotiation fails because parties have different views on 'fair' valuation methodology

failures.name: Fairness Blindness to Power Dynamics
failures.description: Expecting fair treatment when power imbalance makes it unlikely
failures.example_scenario: Small supplier expecting fair treatment from dominant customer without contractual protections

failures.name: Procedural vs. Outcome Fairness Confusion
failures.description: Confusing fair process with fair outcome or vice versa
prevention_strategies: Accept that fair process can yield unfair outcomes
failures.example_scenario: Assuming auction process guarantees fair price when bidders may collude

failures.name: Envy-Driven Analysis Distortion
failures.description: Negative analysis of successful competitors driven by envy rather than facts
failures.example_scenario: Dismissing competitor's success as 'luck' or 'unsustainable' without evidence

failures.name: Keeping Up with Joneses
failures.description: Making decisions based on what others are doing rather than own situation
prevention_strategies: Focus on own situation and goals
failures.example_scenario: Entering market because competitor did, without independent assessment of fit

failures.name: Envy Blindness
failures.description: Failing to recognize envy as a factor in own or others' behavior
prevention_strategies: Consider envy as explanation for behavior
failures.example_scenario: Not understanding why board member opposes CEO's plan (envy of CEO's success)

failures.name: Relative vs. Absolute Performance Confusion
failures.description: Focusing on relative performance vs. peers instead of absolute returns
failures.example_scenario: Feeling bad about 15% return because peers made 20%, ignoring that 15% meets goals

failures.name: Schadenfreude-Driven Misjudgment
failures.description: Pleasure in others' failures leading to underestimation of their recovery
failures.example_scenario: Assuming struggling competitor will fail completely, missing their successful turnaround

failures.name: Reciprocity Manipulation Blindness
failures.description: Failing to recognize when favors are given to manipulate future decisions
failures.example_scenario: Vendor provides expensive gifts before contract renewal negotiation

failures.name: Disproportionate Reciprocation
failures.description: Returning favors far exceeding the original favor's value
failures.example_scenario: Approving large contract because vendor bought lunch

failures.name: Negative Reciprocity Escalation
failures.description: Tit-for-tat retaliation spiraling into destructive conflict
failures.example_scenario: Price war escalating because each side retaliates against the other's cuts

failures.name: Reciprocity Expectation Mismatch
failures.description: Expecting reciprocation that others don't feel obligated to provide
failures.example_scenario: Expecting referrals after providing free consulting, but client doesn't feel obligated

failures.name: Concession Reciprocity Exploitation
failures.description: Being manipulated by door-in-the-face technique (large request then smaller one)
prevention_strategies: Don't feel obligated by others' concessions
failures.example_scenario: Agreeing to unfavorable terms because they're 'better' than initial outrageous ask

failures.name: Messenger-Message Conflation
failures.description: Judging information quality by who delivers it rather than content
failures.example_scenario: Accepting investment thesis because it comes from famous investor without independent analysis

failures.name: Past Success Association
failures.description: Assuming future success because of association with past success
failures.example_scenario: Investing in new fund because manager's previous fund succeeded, without analyzing why

failures.name: Negative Association Contamination
failures.description: Rejecting good ideas because associated with disliked source
failures.example_scenario: Rejecting valid criticism because it comes from a competitor

failures.name: Brand/Prestige Halo
failures.description: Overvaluing things associated with prestigious brands or institutions
failures.example_scenario: Paying premium for McKinsey advice without evaluating if it's better than alternatives

failures.name: Temporal Association Error
failures.description: Assuming causation from temporal association (post hoc ergo propter hoc)
failures.example_scenario: Attributing stock rise to new CEO when it was driven by market-wide rally

failures.name: Reality Denial Detection Failure
failures.description: Failing to recognize when analysis is avoiding painful truths
failures.example_scenario: Analysis avoids discussing possibility that core business is in terminal decline

failures.name: Gradual Decline Denial
failures.description: Denying slow deterioration because each step is small
failures.example_scenario: Not recognizing market share erosion because each quarter's loss is 'small'

failures.name: Sunk Cost Denial
failures.description: Denying that past investments are lost to avoid pain of admitting failure
failures.example_scenario: Continuing failed project because admitting failure is too painful

failures.name: Mortality/Failure Denial
failures.description: Denying that companies/investments can fail completely
failures.example_scenario: Not considering bankruptcy scenario for leveraged company

failures.name: Responsibility Denial
failures.description: Denying own role in failures to avoid psychological pain
failures.example_scenario: Blaming market conditions for poor investment when analysis was flawed

failures.name: Overconfidence in Own Analysis
failures.description: Excessive confidence in own conclusions without adequate uncertainty
failures.example_scenario: Analyst certain of price target without acknowledging wide range of outcomes

failures.name: Endowment Effect in Ideas
failures.description: Overvaluing own ideas simply because they are yours
prevention_strategies: Value ideas by merit not origin
failures.example_scenario: Defending flawed investment thesis because you developed it

failures.name: Above-Average Effect
failures.description: Believing own skills are above average when statistically unlikely
failures.example_scenario: Believing you can beat the market when most professionals can't

failures.name: Self-Serving Attribution
failures.description: Attributing success to skill and failure to luck/circumstances
prevention_strategies: Analyze luck vs. skill in successes
failures.example_scenario: Taking credit for bull market gains while blaming bear market losses on 'unprecedented events'

failures.name: Blind Spot Blindness
failures.description: Believing you are less biased than others
failures.example_scenario: Believing your analysis is objective while others' are biased

failures.name: Planning Fallacy
failures.description: Underestimating time, cost, and risk while overestimating benefits
failures.example_scenario: Project budget and timeline based on best-case scenario

failures.name: Upside Overweighting
failures.description: Focusing on potential gains while underweighting potential losses
prevention_strategies: Equal weight to upside and downside
failures.example_scenario: Investment memo focuses on growth potential with one paragraph on risks

failures.name: Success Rate Overestimation
failures.description: Overestimating probability of success vs. base rates
failures.example_scenario: Assuming 80% chance of successful product launch when base rate is 20%

failures.name: Optimism Contagion
failures.description: Group optimism reinforcing individual optimism
failures.example_scenario: Investment committee all bullish, reinforcing each other's optimism

failures.name: Survivorship Bias in Optimism
failures.description: Optimism based on visible successes while failures are invisible
failures.example_scenario: Optimistic about startup investing based on unicorn examples, ignoring 90% failure rate

failures.name: Loss Aversion Overreaction
failures.description: Disproportionate response to losses leading to poor decisions
failures.example_scenario: Panic selling at market bottom to 'stop the pain'

failures.name: Near-Miss Overvaluation
failures.description: Overvaluing things almost obtained, leading to irrational pursuit
failures.example_scenario: Overpaying for acquisition because you 'almost had it' in previous attempt

failures.name: Status Quo Bias from Loss Framing
failures.description: Preferring status quo because change is framed as loss
failures.example_scenario: Not selling underperforming asset because selling 'locks in the loss'

failures.name: Territorial Defense Overreaction
failures.description: Excessive defense of existing position/market against threats
failures.example_scenario: Destroying profitability to defend market share against new entrant

failures.name: Reference Point Manipulation Blindness
failures.description: Failing to recognize when reference points are being manipulated
failures.example_scenario: Accepting bad deal because it's framed as 'better than' artificially bad alternative

failures.name: Herd Following
failures.description: Following crowd without independent analysis
failures.example_scenario: Buying stock because 'everyone is buying it' without own analysis

failures.name: Expert Consensus Overweighting
failures.description: Overweighting expert consensus without examining underlying reasoning
failures.example_scenario: Accepting analyst consensus price target without understanding assumptions

failures.name: Uncertainty-Driven Social Proof
failures.description: Relying more on social proof when uncertain, amplifying errors
failures.example_scenario: In novel situation, following what others do without questioning if they know better

failures.name: Similarity-Based Social Proof
failures.description: Following people similar to you without evaluating their competence
failures.example_scenario: Following investment strategy of peers without checking their actual returns

failures.name: Cascade Amplification
failures.description: Contributing to information cascade by adding to social proof
failures.example_scenario: Adding bullish view because others are bullish, amplifying potential bubble

failures.name: Anchoring to Wrong Comparison
failures.description: Judging value by contrast to irrelevant anchor
failures.example_scenario: Stock seems cheap at $50 because it was $100, ignoring that fair value is $30

failures.name: Gradual Change Blindness
failures.description: Missing significant changes because each step is small relative to previous
failures.example_scenario: Not noticing margin erosion because each quarter's decline is small

failures.name: Decoy Effect Manipulation
failures.description: Being manipulated by strategically placed inferior option
failures.example_scenario: Choosing expensive option because medium option is strategically priced as decoy

failures.name: Contrast-Based Complacency
failures.description: Accepting bad situation because it's better than worse alternative
prevention_strategies: Don't accept bad because not worst
failures.example_scenario: Accepting poor returns because 'at least we didn't lose money'

failures.name: Salesman's Contrast Trick
failures.description: Being manipulated by showing expensive option first to make target seem reasonable
failures.example_scenario: Buying expensive car because it's cheaper than first one shown

failures.name: Stress-Induced Tunnel Vision
failures.description: Stress narrows focus, missing important peripheral information
failures.example_scenario: During crisis, focusing only on immediate problem while missing related issues

failures.name: Stress-Induced Rigidity
failures.description: Stress causes reversion to familiar patterns even when inappropriate
failures.example_scenario: Applying old playbook to new crisis because stress prevents creative thinking

failures.name: Stress Contagion
failures.description: Stress spreading through team, amplifying poor decision-making
failures.example_scenario: Panic spreading through trading floor leading to collective poor decisions

failures.name: Stress-Performance Curve Misjudgment
failures.description: Not recognizing when stress has crossed from enhancing to impairing performance
failures.example_scenario: Continuing to work through extreme stress when performance has degraded

failures.name: Post-Stress Overconfidence
failures.description: Overconfidence after surviving stressful situation
prevention_strategies: Analyze luck vs. skill in survival
failures.example_scenario: Taking more risk after surviving market crash, believing you can handle anything

failures.name: Recency Bias
failures.description: Overweighting recent events because they are more available in memory
failures.example_scenario: Projecting recent growth rates forward without considering historical cycles

failures.name: Vivid Example Overweighting
failures.description: Overweighting dramatic or vivid examples vs. statistical base rates
failures.example_scenario: Overestimating fraud risk because of memorable fraud case, ignoring low base rate

failures.name: Media Availability Bias
failures.description: Overweighting risks/opportunities that receive media coverage
failures.example_scenario: Overweighting terrorism risk vs. car accidents because of media coverage

failures.name: Personal Experience Overweighting
failures.description: Overweighting own experience vs. broader data
failures.example_scenario: Judging industry based on one company you worked at

failures.name: Ease of Recall Bias
failures.description: Judging frequency/probability by how easily examples come to mind
failures.example_scenario: Overestimating probability of plane crash because crashes are memorable

failures.name: Skill Decay Blindness
failures.description: Not recognizing that unused skills have deteriorated
failures.example_scenario: Assuming you can still do complex analysis you haven't done in years

failures.name: Knowledge Obsolescence
failures.description: Relying on outdated knowledge without updating
failures.example_scenario: Applying investment framework from 20 years ago without updating for changed markets

failures.name: Overreliance on Documented Knowledge
failures.description: Relying on written procedures when tacit knowledge has been lost
failures.example_scenario: Following investment checklist without understanding why each item matters

failures.name: Institutional Memory Loss
failures.description: Organization losing knowledge as experienced people leave
failures.example_scenario: Repeating past mistakes because people who learned from them have left

failures.name: Atrophied Critical Thinking
failures.description: Critical thinking skills decay from disuse in conformist environment
failures.example_scenario: Analyst in yes-man culture loses ability to think critically

failures.name: Impairment Non-Recognition
failures.description: Not recognizing when substances are impairing judgment
failures.example_scenario: Making investment decisions after drinking at dinner meeting

failures.name: Caffeine/Stimulant Overconfidence
failures.description: Stimulants creating false sense of clarity and confidence
failures.example_scenario: Making bold decisions on excessive caffeine that seem less wise later

failures.name: Sleep Deprivation Effects
failures.description: Sleep deprivation impairing judgment similar to intoxication
failures.example_scenario: Making major decisions after all-night work session

failures.name: Medication Side Effects
failures.description: Prescription medications affecting cognitive function unrecognized
failures.example_scenario: Antihistamine causing drowsiness affecting analysis quality

failures.name: Withdrawal Effects
failures.description: Withdrawal from substances affecting judgment
failures.example_scenario: Irritable decision-making during caffeine withdrawal

failures.name: Cognitive Decline Non-Recognition
failures.description: Not recognizing age-related cognitive decline in self or others
failures.example_scenario: Elderly CEO making poor decisions while board doesn't address decline

failures.name: Experience Overweighting vs. Adaptation
failures.description: Overvaluing experience when environment has changed
failures.example_scenario: Applying pre-internet business wisdom to digital-first company

failures.name: Nostalgia Bias
failures.description: Romanticizing past and applying outdated approaches
failures.example_scenario: Preferring old investment style because 'it worked in the good old days'

failures.name: Succession Planning Failure
failures.description: Not planning for cognitive decline or transition
failures.example_scenario: Founder-dependent company with no plan for founder's eventual decline

failures.name: Generational Blind Spots
failures.description: Missing trends or changes due to generational perspective
failures.example_scenario: Dismissing social media importance because 'it's just for kids'

failures.name: Blind Deference to Authority
failures.description: Accepting authority's view without independent evaluation
failures.example_scenario: Accepting CEO's strategy without questioning because of their position

failures.name: False Authority Acceptance
failures.description: Accepting authority in one domain as authority in another
failures.example_scenario: Following famous investor's views on unrelated industry they don't know

failures.name: Authority Symbols Over Substance
failures.description: Responding to symbols of authority (titles, credentials) over actual competence
failures.example_scenario: Trusting advice from PhD without checking if their research is relevant

failures.name: Hierarchical Information Filtering
failures.description: Information distorted as it moves through hierarchy
failures.example_scenario: CEO getting filtered positive information while problems fester below

failures.name: Authority-Induced Groupthink
failures.description: Group conforming to authority's view, suppressing dissent
failures.example_scenario: Board agreeing with CEO's proposal because CEO spoke first and forcefully

failures.name: Trivial Pursuit
failures.description: Spending time on trivial matters while important issues neglected
failures.example_scenario: Spending hours on minor expense while major strategic issue unaddressed

failures.name: Complexity Theater
failures.description: Creating appearance of sophistication through unnecessary complexity
failures.example_scenario: Building complex model when simple analysis would suffice

failures.name: Meeting Proliferation
failures.description: Excessive meetings substituting for actual work
failures.example_scenario: Endless strategy meetings without actual strategic progress

failures.name: Bikeshedding
failures.description: Disproportionate time on trivial issues because they're understandable
failures.example_scenario: Board spending hour on office renovation, minutes on acquisition

failures.name: Activity vs. Progress Confusion
failures.description: Confusing being busy with making progress
failures.example_scenario: Analyst producing many reports but no actionable insights

failures.name: Accepting Poor Reasons
failures.description: Accepting action because a reason is given, even if reason is poor
failures.example_scenario: Accepting strategy change 'because the market is changing' without specifics

failures.name: Reason Fabrication
failures.description: Constructing reasons after the fact to justify decisions
failures.example_scenario: Constructing elaborate justification for intuitive decision after the fact

failures.name: Reason Inflation
failures.description: Inflating importance of reasons to match desired conclusion
failures.example_scenario: Inflating minor positive factors to justify wanted investment

failures.name: Single Reason Sufficiency
failures.description: Accepting single reason as sufficient when multiple should be required
failures.example_scenario: Approving investment based solely on 'great management' without other factors

failures.name: Circular Reasoning Acceptance
failures.description: Accepting circular reasoning because it sounds like a reason
failures.example_scenario: Accepting 'the stock will go up because it's undervalued' without independent valuation

failures.name: Lollapalooza Blindness
failures.description: Failing to recognize when multiple biases are combining
failures.example_scenario: Not recognizing bubble as combination of social proof, overoptimism, and incentives

failures.name: Underestimating Combination Effects
failures.description: Underestimating how biases multiply rather than add
failures.example_scenario: Underestimating fraud risk when incentives, opportunity, and rationalization all present

failures.name: Positive Lollapalooza Overconfidence
failures.description: Overconfidence when multiple positive factors align
failures.example_scenario: Extreme confidence in investment because everything looks perfect

failures.name: Cascade Trigger Failure
failures.description: Not recognizing conditions that could trigger cascading failures
failures.example_scenario: Not seeing how small trigger could cause cascading failures across interconnected system

failures.name: Historical Lollapalooza Amnesia
failures.description: Not learning from historical examples of extreme outcomes
failures.example_scenario: Not recognizing bubble pattern because 'this time the technology is real'

failures.name: Selective Evidence Gathering
failures.description: Only seeking information that confirms existing beliefs
failures.example_scenario: Bull case research only cites positive analyst reports, ignoring critical ones

failures.name: Interpretation Bias
failures.description: Interpreting ambiguous evidence as confirming existing beliefs
failures.example_scenario: Interpreting flat sales as 'stabilization' when bearish view would call it 'stagnation'

failures.name: Memory Bias
failures.description: Remembering confirming evidence better than disconfirming
failures.example_scenario: Remembering successful predictions but forgetting failures

failures.name: Source Selection Bias
failures.description: Choosing sources known to confirm existing views
failures.example_scenario: Only reading bullish analysts on a stock you own

failures.name: Hypothesis Preservation
failures.description: Modifying hypothesis to accommodate contradicting evidence rather than rejecting it
failures.example_scenario: Adding exceptions to investment thesis each time it's challenged rather than reconsidering

failures.name: Outcome-Based Judgment
failures.description: Judging decisions by outcomes rather than process quality
failures.example_scenario: Criticizing investment decision that lost money even though process was sound

failures.name: Predictability Illusion
failures.description: Believing past events were more predictable than they actually were
failures.example_scenario: Claiming 'everyone knew' the bubble would burst after it did

failures.name: Learning Distortion
failures.description: Drawing wrong lessons from past because of hindsight bias
failures.example_scenario: Concluding 'should have sold at the top' without acknowledging it wasn't knowable

failures.name: Creeping Determinism
failures.description: Viewing past as inevitable chain of events
failures.example_scenario: Viewing company's success as inevitable rather than result of many uncertain decisions

failures.name: Overconfidence from Hindsight
failures.description: Becoming overconfident in future predictions because past seems predictable
failures.example_scenario: Believing you can predict next crisis because you 'saw' the last one coming

failures.name: Premature Commitment
failures.description: Committing to first conclusion before adequate analysis
failures.example_scenario: Forming investment opinion after reading one article

failures.name: Anchoring on Initial View
failures.description: Subsequent analysis anchored to and confirming initial conclusion
failures.example_scenario: All subsequent research confirms initial bullish view because that's what you're looking for

failures.name: Cognitive Ease Preference
failures.description: Accepting conclusions that come easily rather than doing hard analysis
failures.example_scenario: Accepting simple narrative rather than doing detailed financial analysis

failures.name: Pattern Matching Shortcut
failures.description: Matching situation to familiar pattern without verifying fit
failures.example_scenario: Assuming company will follow same path as similar company without checking differences

failures.name: Intuition Over Analysis
failures.description: Trusting gut feeling over systematic analysis
failures.example_scenario: Making investment based on 'feeling good' about management without due diligence

failures.name: Irrelevant Anchor Influence
failures.description: Being influenced by anchors that have no logical relevance
failures.example_scenario: Valuation anchored to IPO price which has no bearing on current value

failures.name: Insufficient Adjustment
failures.description: Adjusting insufficiently from anchor even when adjustment is needed
failures.example_scenario: Adjusting analyst price target by 10% when fundamentals suggest 50% change needed

failures.name: Self-Generated Anchor
failures.description: Being anchored by your own previous estimates
failures.example_scenario: Sticking close to your original price target despite changed circumstances

failures.name: Negotiation Anchor Trap
failures.description: Being anchored by counterparty's opening position
failures.example_scenario: Negotiating around seller's asking price rather than your own valuation

failures.name: Historical Price Anchoring
failures.description: Anchoring on historical prices that may no longer be relevant
failures.example_scenario: Thinking stock is cheap because it's down 50% from highs

failures.name: Self-Interest Blindness
failures.description: Not recognizing how own incentives bias analysis
failures.example_scenario: Analyst bullish on stock their firm is underwriting

failures.name: Professional Incentive Distortion
failures.description: Professional incentives unconsciously shaping recommendations
failures.example_scenario: Broker recommending active trading because it generates commissions

failures.name: Institutional Incentive Capture
failures.description: Institutional incentives overriding individual judgment
failures.example_scenario: Analyst maintaining buy rating because firm has banking relationship

failures.name: Incentive Rationalization
failures.description: Constructing rational-sounding justifications for incentive-driven conclusions
failures.example_scenario: Building sophisticated model that happens to justify the deal you want to do

failures.name: Incentive Contagion
failures.description: Adopting others' biased views because of their incentives
failures.example_scenario: Trusting sell-side research without considering their incentives

failures.name: Conditioned Response Blindness
failures.description: Not recognizing conditioned responses driving behavior
failures.example_scenario: Automatically buying dips because it worked before, without analyzing current situation

failures.name: False Association
failures.description: Creating associations between unrelated events
failures.example_scenario: Believing certain market indicators predict outcomes when correlation is spurious

failures.name: Extinction Failure
failures.description: Continuing conditioned response after conditions have changed
prevention_strategies: Regularly review if conditions still apply
failures.example_scenario: Continuing to buy dips in bear market because it worked in bull market

failures.name: Generalization Error
failures.description: Generalizing conditioned response to dissimilar situations
failures.example_scenario: Applying strategy that worked in one market to completely different market

failures.name: Emotional Conditioning
failures.description: Emotional responses conditioned by past experiences distorting judgment
failures.example_scenario: Fear of a sector because of past losses there, even when fundamentals are different

failures.name: Present Bias
failures.description: Overweighting immediate outcomes vs. future outcomes
failures.example_scenario: Selling winning position for immediate gain rather than holding for larger future gain

failures.name: Quarterly Earnings Myopia
failures.description: Overweighting quarterly results vs. long-term value creation
failures.example_scenario: Selling stock after one bad quarter despite strong long-term thesis

failures.name: Impatience with Compounding
failures.description: Undervaluing slow compounding in favor of quick gains
failures.example_scenario: Abandoning 15% compounder for speculative 100% gain attempt

failures.name: Career Risk Short-Termism
failures.description: Short-term focus driven by career risk of underperformance
failures.example_scenario: Avoiding undervalued stock because it might underperform in near term

failures.name: Inconsistent Time Preferences
failures.description: Applying different discount rates to similar future periods
prevention_strategies: Apply same standards to all periods
failures.example_scenario: Heavily discounting year 2 vs year 1, but not year 3 vs year 2

failures.name: Base Rate Neglect
failures.description: Ignoring base rates in favor of representativeness
failures.example_scenario: Assuming startup will succeed because founders fit successful founder stereotype, ignoring 90% failure rate

failures.name: Sample Size Insensitivity
failures.description: Drawing strong conclusions from small samples that seem representative
failures.example_scenario: Concluding strategy works based on 3 successful trades

failures.name: Conjunction Fallacy
failures.description: Judging specific scenarios as more likely than general ones
failures.example_scenario: Believing detailed bull case more likely than simple 'stock goes up'

failures.name: Stereotype Matching
failures.description: Judging probability by fit to stereotype rather than evidence
failures.example_scenario: Assuming company will fail because CEO doesn't fit successful CEO stereotype

failures.name: Regression Ignorance
failures.description: Not expecting regression to mean after extreme observations
failures.example_scenario: Expecting exceptional year to continue rather than regress to average

failures.name: Default Option Preference
failures.description: Preferring current state simply because it's the default
prevention_strategies: Consider opportunity cost of status quo
failures.example_scenario: Keeping underperforming investment because selling requires action

failures.name: Change Aversion
failures.description: Resisting change even when change is beneficial
failures.example_scenario: Not updating investment process despite evidence of better approaches

failures.name: Endowment Effect
failures.description: Overvaluing what you already own
prevention_strategies: Value holdings as if you didn't own them
Would you buy at current price?
failures.example_scenario: Refusing to sell stock at price you wouldn't pay to buy it

failures.name: Process Ossification
failures.description: Continuing processes because 'that's how we've always done it'
failures.example_scenario: Using outdated valuation methods because they're familiar

failures.name: Omission Bias
failures.description: Preferring inaction over action even when action is better
failures.example_scenario: Not selling deteriorating position because selling feels like 'doing something wrong'

failures.name: Inversion Omission
failures.description: Failing to apply inversion when it would reveal important insights
failures.example_scenario: Investment thesis only considers how it could succeed, not how it could fail

failures.name: Superficial Inversion
failures.description: Applying inversion superficially without deep analysis
failures.example_scenario: Risk section lists obvious risks without analyzing probability or impact

failures.name: Inversion Without Action
failures.description: Identifying risks through inversion but not acting on them
failures.example_scenario: Identifying key risk but proceeding without mitigation plan

failures.name: Asymmetric Inversion
failures.description: Applying inversion to some scenarios but not others
failures.example_scenario: Inverting competitive risks but not management risks

failures.name: Inversion Paralysis
failures.description: Excessive focus on what could go wrong preventing action
failures.example_scenario: Never investing because you can always find something that could go wrong

failures.name: Checklist as Checkbox
failures.description: Going through checklist mechanically without genuine analysis
failures.example_scenario: Checking 'competitive advantage: yes' without analyzing what it actually is

failures.name: Incomplete Checklist
failures.description: Checklist missing important items for the situation
failures.example_scenario: Using generic checklist that misses industry-specific risks

failures.name: Checklist Overconfidence
failures.description: False confidence from completing checklist
failures.example_scenario: Feeling confident because checklist is complete, missing non-checklist risks

failures.name: Outdated Checklist
failures.description: Using checklist that hasn't been updated for changed conditions
failures.example_scenario: Using pre-2008 checklist that doesn't include liquidity risk items

failures.name: Checklist Rigidity
failures.description: Following checklist rigidly when situation requires flexibility
failures.example_scenario: Rejecting opportunity because it doesn't fit standard checklist despite unique merits

failures.name: Single Track Dominance
failures.description: One track (rational or psychological) dominates analysis
failures.example_scenario: Pure financial analysis ignoring psychological factors affecting management

failures.name: Track Integration Failure
failures.description: Analyzing both tracks but failing to integrate insights
failures.example_scenario: Rational analysis says buy, psychological says sell, no resolution

failures.name: Psychological Track Superficiality
failures.description: Superficial treatment of psychological factors
failures.example_scenario: Mentioning 'management may be overconfident' without analyzing evidence

failures.name: Self-Analysis Blind Spot
failures.description: Applying two-track to others but not to own analysis
failures.example_scenario: Analyzing target company's biases while ignoring own confirmation bias

failures.name: Rational Track Overconfidence
failures.description: Overconfidence in rational analysis, underweighting psychological
failures.example_scenario: Trusting financial model despite management incentive misalignment

failures.name: Narrow Mental Model Set
failures.description: Using too few mental models, missing important perspectives
failures.example_scenario: Analyzing business only through financial lens, missing psychological and competitive dynamics

failures.name: Model Misapplication
failures.description: Applying mental model to situation where it doesn't fit
failures.example_scenario: Applying supply/demand model to situation driven by network effects

failures.name: Model Overconfidence
failures.description: Excessive confidence in mental model predictions
failures.example_scenario: Treating moat analysis as definitive when moats can erode unexpectedly

failures.name: Model Updating Failure
failures.description: Not updating mental models based on new evidence or failures
failures.example_scenario: Using pre-internet mental models for digital businesses

failures.name: Model Conflict Paralysis
failures.description: Paralysis when different mental models give conflicting answers
failures.example_scenario: Valuation model says buy, competitive analysis says sell, no decision made

failures.name: Isolated Model Application
failures.description: Applying models in isolation rather than as interconnected latticework
failures.example_scenario: Analyzing moat, management, and valuation separately without integration

failures.name: Latticework Gaps
failures.description: Missing important models in the latticework
failures.example_scenario: Latticework missing psychology models, leading to behavioral blind spots

failures.name: Latticework Rigidity
failures.description: Rigid latticework that doesn't adapt to new situations
failures.example_scenario: Applying same latticework to tech startup as to mature industrial company

failures.name: Latticework Complexity Overload
failures.description: Latticework too complex to apply effectively
failures.example_scenario: Trying to apply 50 models to every situation, losing focus

failures.name: Latticework Without Practice
failures.description: Having latticework knowledge without practiced application
failures.example_scenario: Knowing about mental models but not actually using them in analysis

failures.name: Disciplinary Silos
failures.description: Staying within one discipline when multiple are needed
failures.example_scenario: Financial analyst missing psychological factors that drive the business

failures.name: Superficial Multidisciplinarity
failures.description: Surface-level application of other disciplines without deep understanding
failures.example_scenario: Misapplying evolutionary concepts to business without understanding biology

failures.name: Discipline Translation Failure
failures.description: Failing to translate insights between disciplines
failures.example_scenario: Understanding physics concept but not applying it to business situation

failures.name: Discipline Hierarchy Bias
failures.description: Valuing some disciplines over others inappropriately
failures.example_scenario: Dismissing psychology insights because 'it's not as rigorous as finance'

failures.name: Jack of All Trades Trap
failures.description: Broad but shallow knowledge across disciplines
failures.example_scenario: Knowing a little about everything but not enough to apply any discipline well

failures.name: Circle Overestimation
failures.description: Believing circle of competence is larger than it actually is
failures.example_scenario: Tech investor believing they understand biotech because 'it's all science'

failures.name: Circle Boundary Blindness
failures.description: Not knowing where circle of competence ends
failures.example_scenario: Gradually drifting into unfamiliar sectors without recognizing it

failures.name: Circle Stagnation
failures.description: Not expanding circle of competence over time
failures.example_scenario: Retail investor not learning about e-commerce as it transforms retail

failures.name: Circle Shrinkage Denial
failures.description: Not recognizing when competence has eroded
failures.example_scenario: Assuming expertise in industry you haven't followed for years

failures.name: Circle Rigidity
failures.description: Refusing to venture outside circle even when appropriate
failures.example_scenario: Missing great opportunity because it's slightly outside current circle

failures.name: False First Principles
failures.description: Treating assumptions as first principles when they're not fundamental
failures.example_scenario: Treating 'customers want low prices' as first principle when they actually want value

failures.name: Incomplete Decomposition
failures.description: Not breaking problem down to truly fundamental components
failures.example_scenario: Stopping decomposition at 'we need to grow revenue' without breaking down further

failures.name: Reconstruction Failure
failures.description: Decomposing to first principles but failing to reconstruct solution
failures.example_scenario: Understanding fundamental physics but not designing the product

failures.name: First Principles Overuse
failures.description: Using first principles when analogy or convention would be more efficient
failures.example_scenario: Deriving accounting from first principles when GAAP works fine

failures.name: Context-Free First Principles
failures.description: Applying first principles without considering context
failures.example_scenario: First principles say X is optimal but regulatory constraints make it impossible

failures.name: Opportunity Cost Blindness
failures.description: Not considering what else could be done with the same resources
failures.example_scenario: Evaluating investment without considering what else the capital could do

failures.name: Sunk Cost Confusion
failures.description: Confusing sunk costs with opportunity costs
prevention_strategies: Focus on future costs and benefits
failures.example_scenario: Continuing project because of money already spent rather than future opportunity cost

failures.name: Time Opportunity Cost Neglect
failures.description: Not considering the opportunity cost of time
failures.example_scenario: Spending 100 hours on analysis that could have been spent on higher-value activities

failures.name: Attention Opportunity Cost
failures.description: Not considering the opportunity cost of attention and focus
failures.example_scenario: Tracking 50 positions when attention would be better spent on 10

failures.name: Dynamic Opportunity Cost
failures.description: Not updating opportunity cost as circumstances change
failures.example_scenario: Holding investment based on old opportunity cost when better alternatives now exist

failures.name: Static Supply/Demand Analysis
failures.description: Treating supply and demand as static when they're dynamic
failures.example_scenario: Assuming current supply shortage will persist without modeling supply response

failures.name: Elasticity Misjudgment
failures.description: Misjudging price elasticity of supply or demand
failures.example_scenario: Assuming demand will stay constant if prices rise when demand is actually elastic

failures.name: Supply Response Timing
failures.description: Misjudging how quickly supply can respond to price signals
failures.example_scenario: Expecting commodity supply to increase immediately when it takes years to bring new capacity online

failures.name: Demand Substitution Blindness
failures.description: Not considering demand substitution effects
failures.example_scenario: Analyzing oil demand without considering electric vehicle substitution

failures.name: Non-Price Factors Neglect
failures.description: Focusing only on price while ignoring other supply/demand factors
failures.example_scenario: Modeling demand based only on price when quality and brand matter more

failures.name: Artificial Scarcity Confusion
failures.description: Confusing artificial scarcity with true scarcity
failures.example_scenario: Valuing asset based on artificial scarcity that could be eliminated

failures.name: Scarcity Permanence Assumption
failures.description: Assuming current scarcity will persist indefinitely
failures.example_scenario: Assuming rare earth scarcity will persist when recycling and substitutes are developing

failures.name: Scarcity Value Overestimation
failures.description: Overvaluing something simply because it's scarce
failures.example_scenario: Paying premium for scarce asset that has limited practical utility

failures.name: Scarcity Mindset Trap
failures.description: Scarcity mindset leading to suboptimal decisions
failures.example_scenario: Hoarding cash due to scarcity mindset when opportunities abound

failures.name: Relative Scarcity Blindness
failures.description: Not considering relative scarcity across alternatives
failures.example_scenario: Focusing on scarcity of one resource while ignoring more scarce alternatives

failures.name: Diminishing Returns Blindness
failures.description: Not recognizing diminishing marginal utility
failures.example_scenario: Continuing to add features when marginal utility to customers is near zero

failures.name: Average vs Marginal Confusion
failures.description: Confusing average utility with marginal utility
failures.example_scenario: Expanding production because average profit is good when marginal profit is negative

failures.name: Utility Function Misspecification
failures.description: Incorrectly specifying what creates utility
failures.example_scenario: Assuming customers value features when they actually value simplicity

failures.name: Interpersonal Utility Comparison
failures.description: Incorrectly comparing utility across different people
failures.example_scenario: Assuming all customers have same utility function when preferences vary widely

failures.name: Negative Marginal Utility Blindness
failures.description: Not recognizing when marginal utility becomes negative
failures.example_scenario: Adding more information to report when it actually reduces usefulness

failures.name: Absolute vs Comparative Confusion
failures.description: Confusing absolute advantage with comparative advantage
failures.example_scenario: Insourcing activity because you're good at it, ignoring you're even better at something else

failures.name: Static Comparative Advantage
failures.description: Treating comparative advantage as static when it evolves
failures.example_scenario: Relying on current comparative advantage without building future capabilities

failures.name: Comparative Advantage Erosion
failures.description: Not recognizing erosion of comparative advantage
failures.example_scenario: Assuming cost advantage will persist while competitors are catching up

failures.name: Narrow Comparative Advantage View
failures.description: Defining comparative advantage too narrowly
failures.example_scenario: Focusing on manufacturing advantage while missing distribution advantage

failures.name: Comparative Advantage Overconfidence
failures.description: Overconfidence in sustainability of comparative advantage
failures.example_scenario: Believing brand advantage is permanent when customer preferences are shifting

failures.name: Trade-off Denial
failures.description: Believing you can have it all without trade-offs
failures.example_scenario: Strategy claiming to be lowest cost AND most differentiated without acknowledging tension

failures.name: Hidden Trade-off Blindness
failures.description: Not seeing hidden or delayed trade-offs
failures.example_scenario: Cost cutting that saves money now but damages capabilities for future

failures.name: Trade-off Quantification Failure
failures.description: Not quantifying trade-offs to enable comparison
failures.example_scenario: Knowing there's a quality-cost trade-off but not quantifying the relationship

failures.name: False Trade-off Acceptance
failures.description: Accepting trade-offs that don't actually exist
failures.example_scenario: Accepting speed-quality trade-off when process improvement could deliver both

failures.name: Trade-off Timing Mismatch
failures.description: Not considering when trade-offs materialize
failures.example_scenario: Choosing option with immediate benefit ignoring larger delayed cost

failures.name: Incentive Mapping Failure
failures.description: Not mapping all relevant incentives in a situation
failures.example_scenario: Analyzing company without understanding management's personal incentives

failures.name: Incentive Alignment Assumption
failures.description: Assuming incentives are aligned when they're not
failures.example_scenario: Trusting management recommendations without checking their incentives

failures.name: Incentive Gaming Blindness
failures.description: Not anticipating how incentives will be gamed
failures.example_scenario: Setting sales targets without considering how they might be gamed

failures.name: Non-Financial Incentive Neglect
failures.description: Focusing only on financial incentives
failures.example_scenario: Analyzing CEO behavior based only on compensation, missing empire-building motivation

failures.name: Incentive Change Blindness
failures.description: Not recognizing when incentives have changed
failures.example_scenario: Expecting same behavior after compensation structure changed

failures.name: Externality Blindness
failures.description: Not identifying externalities in analysis
failures.example_scenario: Valuing company without considering environmental externalities that may be regulated

failures.name: Externality Internalization Risk
failures.description: Not anticipating when externalities will be internalized
failures.example_scenario: Valuing polluter without considering carbon pricing risk

failures.name: Positive Externality Neglect
failures.description: Focusing only on negative externalities, missing positive ones
failures.example_scenario: Missing platform value because positive network externalities not considered

failures.name: Externality Quantification Failure
failures.description: Not quantifying externalities for proper analysis
failures.example_scenario: Acknowledging environmental impact but not estimating potential liability

failures.name: Externality Attribution Error
failures.description: Incorrectly attributing externalities to wrong source
failures.example_scenario: Blaming downstream company for upstream pollution

failures.name: Scale Economies Overestimation
failures.description: Overestimating the magnitude of scale economies
failures.example_scenario: Projecting 50% cost reduction from scale when industry shows 20%

failures.name: Diseconomies of Scale Blindness
failures.description: Not recognizing diseconomies that emerge at large scale
failures.example_scenario: Assuming bigger is always better without considering bureaucracy costs

failures.name: Scale Timing Misjudgment
failures.description: Misjudging how quickly scale economies can be achieved
failures.example_scenario: Expecting immediate cost benefits from acquisition when integration takes years

failures.name: Scale Source Confusion
failures.description: Not understanding the source of scale economies
failures.example_scenario: Assuming scale benefits from volume when they actually come from scope

failures.name: Minimum Efficient Scale Misjudgment
failures.description: Misjudging the minimum efficient scale for an industry
failures.example_scenario: Entering market at scale below minimum efficient scale

failures.name: Network Effect Existence Assumption
failures.description: Assuming network effects exist when they don't
failures.example_scenario: Claiming network effects for product where user value doesn't increase with more users

failures.name: Network Effect Strength Overestimation
failures.description: Overestimating the strength of network effects
failures.example_scenario: Assuming winner-take-all when users easily multi-home across platforms

failures.name: Negative Network Effects Blindness
failures.description: Not recognizing negative network effects
failures.example_scenario: Not recognizing that more users degrade experience through congestion or spam

failures.name: Network Effect Timing
failures.description: Misjudging when network effects kick in or plateau
failures.example_scenario: Expecting immediate network effects when critical mass hasn't been reached

failures.name: Local vs Global Network Effects
failures.description: Confusing local and global network effects
failures.example_scenario: Assuming global network effects for marketplace that's actually local

failures.name: Switching Cost Overestimation
failures.description: Overestimating customer switching costs
failures.example_scenario: Assuming customers are locked in when they're actually switching to competitors

failures.name: Switching Cost Erosion
failures.description: Not recognizing erosion of switching costs over time
failures.example_scenario: Assuming data migration costs will persist when tools make migration easy

failures.name: Switching Cost Type Confusion
failures.description: Not distinguishing between different types of switching costs
failures.example_scenario: Treating financial and learning switching costs the same when they behave differently

failures.name: Switching Cost Asymmetry
failures.description: Not recognizing asymmetric switching costs
failures.example_scenario: Assuming switching costs work both ways when it's easier to switch out than in

failures.name: Switching Cost vs Value Confusion
failures.description: Confusing switching costs with genuine value creation
failures.example_scenario: Interpreting low churn as customer satisfaction when it's actually high switching costs

failures.name: Moat Existence Assumption
failures.description: Assuming moat exists without verification
failures.example_scenario: Claiming brand moat when brand doesn't command pricing power

failures.name: Moat Durability Overestimation
failures.description: Overestimating how long moat will last
failures.example_scenario: Assuming 20-year moat when technology could disrupt in 5 years

failures.name: Moat Width Misjudgment
failures.description: Misjudging the width/strength of the moat
failures.example_scenario: Calling it a wide moat when margins are under constant pressure

failures.name: Moat Source Misidentification
failures.description: Misidentifying the source of competitive advantage
failures.example_scenario: Attributing success to brand when it's actually distribution

failures.name: Moat Reinforcement Failure
failures.description: Not recognizing when moat is being reinforced or weakened
failures.example_scenario: Missing that competitor is systematically eroding your moat

failures.name: Disruption Denial
failures.description: Denying or dismissing disruption threats
failures.example_scenario: Dismissing new technology as 'not good enough' when it's improving rapidly

failures.name: Disruption Timing Misjudgment
failures.description: Misjudging the timing of creative destruction
failures.example_scenario: Expecting immediate disruption when adoption takes decades

failures.name: Disruption Path Blindness
failures.description: Not seeing the path disruption will take
failures.example_scenario: Missing that disruption will come from low end of market

failures.name: Creative Destruction Opportunity Miss
failures.description: Seeing only threat, missing opportunity in creative destruction
failures.example_scenario: Focusing on defending against disruption instead of benefiting from it

failures.name: Destruction Without Creation
failures.description: Expecting destruction without understanding what's being created
failures.example_scenario: Predicting industry destruction without identifying who captures new value

failures.name: Over-Specialization Risk
failures.description: Specializing too narrowly, creating fragility
failures.example_scenario: Company so specialized that single customer loss is existential

failures.name: Specialization Obsolescence
failures.description: Specialization becoming obsolete due to change
failures.example_scenario: Deep expertise in technology that's being replaced

failures.name: Specialization vs Generalization Trade-off
failures.description: Not optimizing the specialization-generalization trade-off
failures.example_scenario: Generalizing when market rewards specialization or vice versa

failures.name: Specialization Coordination Failure
failures.description: Specialization without proper coordination mechanisms
failures.example_scenario: Specialized teams that can't work together effectively

failures.name: False Specialization
failures.description: Claiming specialization without true expertise
failures.example_scenario: Claiming industry specialization with only surface-level knowledge

failures.name: Stuck in the Middle
failures.description: Being stuck in middle without advantages of either extreme
failures.example_scenario: Company neither cheapest nor best, losing to both

failures.name: Middle Position Erosion
failures.description: Middle position being squeezed from both ends
failures.example_scenario: Mid-market retailer squeezed by discounters and premium players

failures.name: False Middle Opportunity
failures.description: Seeing middle opportunity that doesn't exist
failures.example_scenario: Launching mid-tier product when customers want cheap or premium only

failures.name: Middle Differentiation Failure
failures.description: Failing to differentiate middle position
failures.example_scenario: Middle position with no clear reason for customers to choose it

failures.name: Middle Scaling Challenge
failures.description: Not recognizing scaling challenges of middle position
failures.example_scenario: Middle position that can't achieve scale economies or premium pricing

failures.name: IP Value Overestimation
failures.description: Overestimating the value of intellectual property
failures.example_scenario: Valuing patent portfolio highly when patents are easily designed around

failures.name: IP Expiration Blindness
failures.description: Not planning for IP expiration
failures.example_scenario: Pharma company without plan for patent cliff

failures.name: IP Enforcement Assumption
failures.description: Assuming IP can be easily enforced
failures.example_scenario: Assuming patent will stop competitors when enforcement is costly and uncertain

failures.name: IP vs Real Advantage Confusion
failures.description: Confusing IP protection with real competitive advantage
failures.example_scenario: Relying solely on patents when execution and brand matter more

failures.name: IP Landscape Blindness
failures.description: Not understanding the broader IP landscape
failures.example_scenario: Launching product without checking for blocking patents

failures.name: Off-Balance Sheet Blindness
failures.description: Missing off-balance sheet items
failures.example_scenario: Missing operating lease liabilities that are effectively debt

failures.name: Accounting Policy Blindness
failures.description: Not understanding impact of accounting policy choices
failures.example_scenario: Comparing companies without adjusting for different revenue recognition policies

failures.name: Accrual vs Cash Confusion
failures.description: Confusing accrual accounting with cash reality
failures.example_scenario: Trusting reported earnings when cash flow tells different story

failures.name: Balance Sheet Quality Blindness
failures.description: Not analyzing quality of balance sheet items
failures.example_scenario: Trusting asset values without analyzing collectibility or obsolescence

failures.name: Accounting Manipulation Blindness
failures.description: Not detecting accounting manipulation
failures.example_scenario: Missing revenue manipulation through channel stuffing

failures.name: Utility Function Misspecification
failures.description: Incorrectly specifying utility function
failures.example_scenario: Assuming customers maximize price when they actually maximize convenience

failures.name: Utility Heterogeneity Blindness
failures.description: Assuming homogeneous utility when it varies
failures.example_scenario: Single product for market with diverse utility functions

failures.name: Utility Stability Assumption
failures.description: Assuming utility functions are stable when they change
failures.example_scenario: Assuming customer preferences are stable when they're shifting

failures.name: Stated vs Revealed Preference Gap
failures.description: Trusting stated preferences over revealed preferences
failures.example_scenario: Trusting survey saying customers want feature they don't actually use

failures.name: Utility Maximization Assumption
failures.description: Assuming rational utility maximization when behavior is bounded
failures.example_scenario: Modeling customer as perfect optimizer when they satisfice

failures.name: Diminishing Returns Timing
failures.description: Misjudging when diminishing returns set in
failures.example_scenario: Continuing to invest past point of diminishing returns

failures.name: Increasing Returns Confusion
failures.description: Confusing increasing returns phase with permanent condition
failures.example_scenario: Assuming growth rates will continue when approaching saturation

failures.name: Input-Specific Diminishing Returns
failures.description: Not recognizing which inputs face diminishing returns
failures.example_scenario: Adding more salespeople when marketing is the bottleneck

failures.name: Diminishing Returns vs Negative Returns
failures.description: Not recognizing when returns become negative
failures.example_scenario: Adding features that actually reduce product value

failures.name: Diminishing Returns Across Dimensions
failures.description: Not considering diminishing returns across different dimensions
failures.example_scenario: Optimizing one metric past diminishing returns while others are neglected

failures.name: Bottleneck Misidentification
failures.description: Identifying wrong bottleneck
failures.example_scenario: Optimizing production when sales is the actual bottleneck

failures.name: Bottleneck Shifting
failures.description: Not anticipating bottleneck shift after fixing current one
failures.example_scenario: Fixing production bottleneck only to hit distribution bottleneck

failures.name: Bottleneck Optimization Myopia
failures.description: Optimizing non-bottleneck while ignoring actual bottleneck
failures.example_scenario: Improving efficient process while bottleneck process is ignored

failures.name: Hidden Bottleneck Blindness
failures.description: Not seeing hidden or soft bottlenecks
failures.example_scenario: Missing that management attention is the real bottleneck

failures.name: Bottleneck Exploitation Failure
failures.description: Not fully exploiting bottleneck before trying to expand it
failures.example_scenario: Adding capacity when existing bottleneck has downtime

failures.name: Game Structure Misidentification
failures.description: Misidentifying situation as prisoner's dilemma when it's not
failures.example_scenario: Treating coordination game as prisoner's dilemma

failures.name: One-Shot vs Repeated Game Confusion
failures.description: Treating repeated game as one-shot or vice versa
failures.example_scenario: Defecting in repeated game where cooperation would be sustained

failures.name: Payoff Estimation Error
failures.description: Incorrectly estimating payoffs in the game
failures.example_scenario: Underestimating reputational cost of defection

failures.name: Player Identification Failure
failures.description: Not identifying all relevant players in the game
failures.example_scenario: Modeling two-player game when third party affects outcomes

failures.name: Escape Route Blindness
failures.description: Not seeing ways to escape the dilemma
failures.example_scenario: Accepting price war as inevitable when coordination is possible

failures.name: Commons Identification Failure
failures.description: Not recognizing common resource dynamics
failures.example_scenario: Not recognizing that industry is depleting shared customer goodwill

failures.name: Tragedy Timing Misjudgment
failures.description: Misjudging when tragedy will occur
failures.example_scenario: Assuming resource will last longer than it actually does

failures.name: Governance Solution Blindness
failures.description: Not seeing governance solutions to commons problems
failures.example_scenario: Assuming overfishing is inevitable when quota systems could work

failures.name: Private vs Common Confusion
failures.description: Confusing private and common resources
failures.example_scenario: Treating common resource as private, ignoring external effects

failures.name: Free Rider Underestimation
failures.description: Underestimating free rider problem in commons
failures.example_scenario: Assuming all players will cooperate in conservation without enforcement

failures.name: Bad Driving Out Good Blindness
failures.description: Not recognizing when bad is driving out good
failures.example_scenario: Not noticing that low-quality competitors are driving out quality players

failures.name: Gresham Dynamics Timing
failures.description: Misjudging speed of Gresham's Law dynamics
failures.example_scenario: Assuming quality erosion will be gradual when it accelerates suddenly

failures.name: Information Asymmetry Role
failures.description: Not recognizing role of information asymmetry in Gresham dynamics
failures.example_scenario: Quality products losing to inferior ones because customers can't tell difference

failures.name: Gresham Reversal Opportunity
failures.description: Missing opportunity to reverse Gresham dynamics
failures.example_scenario: Not creating premium segment to escape race to bottom

failures.name: Gresham in Non-Monetary Contexts
failures.description: Not applying Gresham's Law to non-monetary situations
failures.example_scenario: Missing that bad behavior is driving out good in organizational culture

failures.name: Algorithm Overconfidence
failures.description: Excessive confidence in algorithmic outputs
failures.example_scenario: Trusting model output without understanding assumptions and limitations

failures.name: Algorithm Bias Blindness
failures.description: Not recognizing biases embedded in algorithms
failures.example_scenario: Using biased algorithm without recognizing systematic errors

failures.name: Algorithm Brittleness
failures.description: Not recognizing algorithm brittleness outside training distribution
failures.example_scenario: Algorithm fails in new market conditions it wasn't trained on

failures.name: Algorithm Feedback Loop
failures.description: Not recognizing feedback loops created by algorithms
failures.example_scenario: Trading algorithm creating the patterns it's designed to exploit

failures.name: Algorithm vs Judgment Balance
failures.description: Wrong balance between algorithm and human judgment
failures.example_scenario: Following algorithm in situation requiring human judgment

failures.name: Compounding Underestimation
failures.description: Underestimating the power of compounding over time
failures.example_scenario: Preferring 10% one-time gain over 2% annual compounding

failures.name: Negative Compounding Blindness
failures.description: Not recognizing negative compounding effects
failures.example_scenario: Ignoring small annual market share losses that compound to major decline

failures.name: Compounding Interruption Risk
failures.description: Not protecting compounding from interruption
failures.example_scenario: Taking risks that could interrupt long-term compounding

failures.name: Compounding Rate Sensitivity
failures.description: Not recognizing sensitivity to compounding rate
failures.example_scenario: Dismissing 1% fee difference that compounds to huge difference over time

failures.name: Compounding Base Neglect
failures.description: Focusing on rate while neglecting base
failures.example_scenario: Chasing high return rate on small base vs lower rate on large base

failures.name: Base Rate Neglect
failures.description: Ignoring base rates in probability assessment
failures.example_scenario: Estimating startup success probability without considering 90% failure base rate

failures.name: Conjunction Fallacy
failures.description: Judging conjunction of events as more likely than single event
failures.example_scenario: Believing detailed scenario more likely than simple outcome

failures.name: Independence Assumption Error
failures.description: Assuming independence when events are correlated
failures.example_scenario: Assuming diversified portfolio when holdings are correlated

failures.name: Small Probability Misjudgment
failures.description: Misjudging small probabilities (over or underweighting)
failures.example_scenario: Ignoring 1% probability event that would be catastrophic

failures.name: Probability vs Frequency Confusion
failures.description: Confusing probability with frequency
failures.example_scenario: Expecting 50% probability to mean exactly half in small sample

failures.name: Combinatorial Explosion Blindness
failures.description: Not recognizing combinatorial explosion
failures.example_scenario: Underestimating number of possible scenarios to analyze

failures.name: Order Relevance Error
failures.description: Confusing when order matters vs doesn't
failures.example_scenario: Using combinations when permutations needed or vice versa

failures.name: Sampling Without Replacement Error
failures.description: Confusing sampling with and without replacement
failures.example_scenario: Calculating probability assuming replacement when sampling without

failures.name: Subset Selection Bias
failures.description: Biased selection of subsets to analyze
failures.example_scenario: Analyzing only favorable combinations of factors

failures.name: Interaction Effect Blindness
failures.description: Not considering interaction effects in combinations
failures.example_scenario: Assuming factors combine additively when they interact

failures.name: False Equivalence
failures.description: Treating non-equivalent things as equivalent
failures.example_scenario: Treating two metrics as equivalent when they measure different things

failures.name: Hidden Variable Blindness
failures.description: Missing hidden variables that break equivalence
failures.example_scenario: Assuming two strategies are equivalent without seeing hidden cost differences

failures.name: Transformation Error
failures.description: Errors in algebraic transformation
failures.example_scenario: Mathematical error in converting between equivalent forms

failures.name: Context-Dependent Equivalence
failures.description: Not recognizing equivalence depends on context
failures.example_scenario: Assuming equivalence holds in new context without verification

failures.name: Practical vs Theoretical Equivalence
failures.description: Confusing theoretical and practical equivalence
failures.example_scenario: Theoretically equivalent strategies with different practical outcomes

failures.name: Pattern in Randomness
failures.description: Seeing patterns in random data
failures.example_scenario: Finding 'predictive' pattern in random stock movements

failures.name: Randomness Denial
failures.description: Denying role of randomness in outcomes
failures.example_scenario: Attributing success entirely to skill when luck played major role

failures.name: Gambler's Fallacy
failures.description: Believing past random events affect future probabilities
failures.example_scenario: Believing stock is 'due' to go up after string of losses

failures.name: Hot Hand Fallacy
failures.description: Believing in streaks in random processes
failures.example_scenario: Believing trader is 'hot' when recent success is random

failures.name: Randomness Source Confusion
failures.description: Confusing different sources of randomness
failures.example_scenario: Treating reducible uncertainty as irreducible randomness

failures.name: Process Misspecification
failures.description: Using wrong stochastic process model
failures.example_scenario: Assuming normal distribution when fat tails exist

failures.name: Stationarity Assumption Error
failures.description: Assuming stationarity when process is non-stationary
failures.example_scenario: Using historical volatility when volatility regime has changed

failures.name: Path Dependency Blindness
failures.description: Not recognizing path dependency in process
failures.example_scenario: Ignoring that current state depends on path taken to get there

failures.name: Ergodicity Confusion
failures.description: Confusing ensemble and time averages
failures.example_scenario: Using average return when individual paths can go to zero

failures.name: Tail Event Underestimation
failures.description: Underestimating probability of tail events
failures.example_scenario: Risk model underestimating probability of market crash
